abstract.text: A behavior that applies a continuous or instantaneous force to one or more dynamic items, causing those items to change position accordingly.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A
dynamic item
is any iOS or custom object that conforms to the
protocol. The
and

classes implement this protocol starting in iOS 7.0. You can use a custom object as a dynamic item for such purposes as reacting to rotation or position changes computed by a dynamic animator—an instance of the
class.
The default magnitude of a push behavior’s force vector is
, equivalent to no force. A continuous force vector with a magnitude of
, applied to a 100 point x 100 point view whose density value is
, results in view acceleration of 100 points / second² in the direction of the vector; this value is also known as the UIKit Newton.
You express a push behavior’s force vector in terms of magnitude (
) and radian angle (
). Instead of using radian angle, you can equivalently express direction using
x
and
y
components by using the
property. Whichever approach you use, the alternate, equivalent values update automatically.
For each dynamic item that you associate with a push, the force is applied at the item center or at a specified offset from the center in item-relative coordinates.
To use a push behavior with a dynamic item, perform these two steps:
Associate the item with the behavior using the
method, or initialize a new push behavior with an array of items using the
method
Enable the behavior by adding it to an animator using the
method
After enabling a push behavior, you can activate it and deactivate it using the
property.

The coordinate system that pertains to a push behavior, and the types of dynamic items you can use with the behavior, depend on how you initialized the associated animator. For details, read the Overview of
You can include a push behavior in a custom, composite behavior by starting with a
object and adding a push behavior with the
method.  If you want to influence a push behavior at each step of a dynamic animation, implement the inherited
method.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A relationship between two dynamic items, or between a dynamic item and an anchor point.
A layout object that manages the layout-related attributes for a given item in a collection view.
An object that confers to a specified array of dynamic items the ability to engage in collisions with each other and with the behavior’s specified boundaries.
An object that provides physics-related capabilities and animations for its dynamic items, and provides the context for those animations.
Adds a dynamic behavior to a dynamic animator.
An object that confers a behavioral configuration on one or more dynamic items, for their participation in 2D animation.
The block you want to execute during dynamic animation.
Adds a dynamic behavior, as a child, to a custom dynamic behavior.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
An object that applies field-based physics to dynamic items.
An object that applies a gravity-like force to all of its associated dynamic items.
A behavior that applies a continuous or instantaneous force to one or more dynamic items, causing those items to change position accordingly.
The type of force for the push behavior.
The state of the push behavior’s force: either active or inactive.
Adds a dynamic item to the behavior’s dynamic item array.
The angle, in radians, of the force vector for the behavior.
Initializes a push behavior with an array of dynamic items.
Returns the set of dynamic items you’ve added to the push behavior.
The magnitude of the force vector for the push behavior.
Returns the force mode for the push behavior.
The direction of the force vector for the behavior, expressed as

inlineContent.text: x

abstract.text: and

inlineContent.text: y

abstract.text: components and using standard UIKit geometry.
Removes a specific dynamic item from the behavior.
Sets the angle and magnitude of the force vector for the behavior.
Sets the offset, from the center of a dynamic item, at which to apply the push behavior’s force vector.
Returns the offset, from the center of a dynamic item, at which the push behavior’s force vector is applied.
A spring-like behavior whose initial motion is damped over time so that the object settles at a specific point.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
